Trying to make some sense of Matt's death keeps sending me back to
reading Euripes' Alcestis as an undergraduate. In the play, Herakles
strides in and when he finds Alcestis' family in mourning, traipses
into Hades and brings the the princess back from the land of the dead
without hesitation. In the play, Herakles is a bit swaggering, larger
than life, practically laughing at the face of adversity, but strongly
a man of both great passion and his word. He's invincible, he's a hero.

And then I realize that my brain is tricking me. I'm still thinking of
Elvis. The part of me that still relates life to books is still showing
me what I keep thinking. That any minute, in the next act, Elvis should
be striding in here bigger than life, straight from the afterlife,
with a princess over his shoulder, as if it were just the next thing
he should do.

Once, when I tried to describe Elvis, I said it was as if he seemed
bigger than life. And The Girl responded, "that's because he is." And
it's true. Not that he wasn't very real, and very full of life.
Instead, that's why he seemed so much bigger, and why this is harder

I just finished Generation Me by Dr. Jean M. Twenge of San Diego State University. Recently, I had been exchanging posts with about the author's research on narcissism in young Americans and her theories linking narcissism to self-esteem courses given to pre-schoolers and young school-agers and to similar themes in popular culture. Shortly thereafter I had the opportunity to listen to Dr. Twenge speak at a professional conference, and after that, I decided to pick up her book. Note that the book is not a scholarly tome -- it is very much written for the mass market. This isn't a bad thing, but that does mean that the scholarly research tends to be buried in the book a little bit -- numbers and methods glossed over quickly, correlations and conclusions brought out with minimal discussion of the means by which the author achieved them. All of this is acceptable, but leaves me with a bit of an empty feeling scholastically. And in the end, I find her conclusions unsatisfactory. Here's the thing -- she has some very good research tracing the rise of narcissism, isolation and stress among college students, demonstrated strongly over time, with corroborating evidence that similar trends are happening among the more diverse population of school-age children. But linking this to self-esteem training is problematic, since it is not the only variable. And the tracking of only students and not the general population does not isolate this variable. If narcissism has had a linear increase among students since 1970, but this is not shown in the general population nor is it shown in older adults who graduated before widespread use of self-esteem curriculum, then there is a strong correlation between self-esteem training. Otherwise... well, we can say strongly that there has been an increase since 1970. But her data only compare students at the moment of college. So what if baby boomers were only half as narcissistic at age 20 as current college students if we don't know whether they, too, have become twice as narcissistic over the same period of time. Is it this generation who are narcissistic, isolated and stressed out, or is it a broader social pattern? That isn't clear in the research she presents. Moreover, I'm not convinced that self-esteem training is the cause. My pet theory would be that these personality traits (which seem consistent and linear in her data) would be linked not to self-esteem training but to social trends driven by the growth of consumerism in the United States. The post-WWII economic growth drove a major change in American economic expectations, family structure, living patterns, and familial distribution. It also led to a huge rise in advertising, production, wealth and property ownership, driving a major trend toward consumerism, materialism, and high expectations for ongoing productivity. My theory would be that, in fact, self-esteem training is a symptom of this economic trend and its social impact, including the treatment of children as a matter of status, achievement and expressions of personal value. In short, I think she's treating a symptom as a cause, myself. Then again, I like to listen to Economist magazine's weekly podcast, and would subscribe to it if I had the $98/year to cover the subscription, so I'm putting a bias on the table.

Like most role-playing gamers, somewhere in the back of my head is a part of me that always analyzes the mechanics and tries to come up with house rules or changes to make game x work more like I imagine it should. Lately, however, while I have no game group, my brain has been tearing apart the usual games I play in frustration as I try to find something that matches my tastes more. What I have been looking for is a simple, free-form game to play a more swashbuckling fantasy game. I went so far as unearthing my copy of Jonathan Tweet's Everway to no avail. Still wasn't right. I wanted more of a sense of changing fortunes, more ability for players to manage resources to consider their options. I ended up deciding that Everway did have some good ideas to mine, but that I wanted to focus on a card-based mechanic. My idea is to pilfer Everway's basic character generation, but to have characters defined by four stats governed by the four suits of a standard deck of cards: Finesse (Spades); Physique (Clubs); Charisma (Hearts); and Intellect (Diamonds). Characters can divide 15 points between these four traits, and then gain a specialization in each area, defined by the player but relating to each trait. Conflict resolution will be resolved with a deck of playing cards. Any conflict will be defined by the GM based on an element. Solving a puzzle might be a diamonds challenge, a fencing match a spades challenge, a round of verbal sparring a hearts challenge, etc. The size of a player's hand is equal to the player's suit rating, plus 1 if the challenge matches a character's specialization. The GM's hand size is a bit trickier. I don't want to manage multiple hands, so here goes:
  1. There are named (major) and unnamed (supporting) NPCs.
  2. Named NPCs are statted up as normal. Unnamed NPCs are rated as ordinary (1 card) or extraordinary (2 card) NPCs.
  3. The GMs hand is based on the appropriate suit of the highest-ranked named NPC, +2 cards for every other named PC, +2 cards per extraordinary unnamed NPC, +1 car for each ordinary unnamed NPC.
Play starts with the lowest-ranked player (or GM), and goes clockwise. The starting player bids first, with each round taken by the high card of the same suit. However, the suit of the challenge is considered trump for that challenge. Each bid won gives a boon to the winner. That can be used to eliminate an unnamed NPC, damage a trait of a named NPC or PC, or change the conditions of the battle (perhaps giving a bonus card or other advantage to a player). Each round of play should be role-played as cards are played, using the shifting balance of the cards as cues. Once the last player plays his last card, the battle is either over or, at GM call, a new set of cards can be dealt out, but with one fewer card for every player. So that's what I have. A bare skeleton of a simple RPG game. I have ideas for a setting already, and am not sure what fantastic elements I want to add. This intentionally avoids things like special rules for equipment and weapons, and is very vague to promote free-form play. Not sure it will work. Maybe it's time to really write this up and try some playtesting.

Yesterday, Steve "the Crocodile Hunter" Irwin died in a freak accident - stung in the chest by a stingray while filming a documentary. Strange way to go for a man who has wrestled salt-water crocodiles, been chased by komodo dragons, and handled more venomous snakes than seems reasonable. Then -- cardiac arrest brought on by a creature considered to be venomous enough to be a serious nuisance, but not deadly.

While it was easy to laugh at his enthusiasm and bigger-than-life persona -- and I think more than a little intentionally so -- Steve Irwin brought to the world a passion for and awareness of the wonders of reptiles and large predators that I still admire. Helps that I like both, myself. But in a world where reptiles are seen as creepy and their elimination as a Good Thing, and even more in a world where large predators are feared and treated as a threat to farming, industry and profits, having someone champion them in the public eye was a wonderful thing.

Sometimes it seemed like the man was invulnerable, his enthusiasm enough to part seas and make him unstoppable. But sometimes, working with wild animals has dangers you can't predict. Or stop, even with a giant heart and huge passions. 

The world will be a duller, colder place without you, mate.

Appararently Pluto has been downsized. This isn't a matter of solar system cost-cutting to improve its standing of the galactic stock exchange or to please our alien shareholders, but a matter of astronomers apparently trying to get some sort of definition of what the hell a planet is. Pluto, along with the asteroid Ceres and big-ass frozen rock designated 2003 UB313, but nicknamed Xena by some cheeky (and definitely geeky) American astronomers, now gets to sit at the solar system kids table of sorts. The students I went to college with were, as a group, impatient and lazy. We dislike authority, we dislike having to pay dues, and we disliked imposed structure. To us, it was all bullshit that slowed us down. In some ways we were right, but often we were wrong about that, but that's what we saw. It's not that we didn't want to work or do stuff, we just wanted to get past all the stuff we thought was unimportant and get to the good stuff. Paying dues was the way the man kept us down. We didn't buy the idea that paying dues was part of the process of earning a place at the adult table. That, in a nutshell, was the heart of life as a slacker from Generation X. That said, most of my classmates were smart, even when they were stoned. They had as long an attention span as a hyperactive squirrel on crack, but we loved to gather information, sythesize it, true new things, and then get drunk or stoned and fuck, then complain a lot that we were never going to have any money. We argued with our parents, forged families of choice, and learned most of what we wanted from reading, TV, and talking to people at parties who had interesting things to say and stole their lines.

So when I see the students I see on my campus, who have taken many more Advanced Placement and International Baccalaureate exams, who have taken more college courses in high school, who have mapped out their lives and done all the right things and own planners and have gone through academic tutoring and coaching; who have parents who are very supportive and mentoring; who join Christian clubs and don't spend their days drunk and stoned in the dorms, why is it that I talk to them and tend to find them much less lucid and clever than the kids I went to school with? I mean, this is a top school in sciences and technology. I went to a third-tier UC campus. We were the troubled kid in the UC system nobody liked to talk about. The slackerest of slacker schools. But despite that, we seemed better prepared to think, live and create. Sure, we bitched and moaned and thought we should just move into the executive suite -- and some of us did (go dot-com boom!) just before loosing everything rather quickly (thanks to the dot-bomb debacle). But in the end, we were pretty clever, if far too whiny and lazy.

The students I see today seem on the surface to be more together and more structured. But a lot of that seems to be surface. They can pass tests, but they don't know what they learned and why. They can't synthesize or analyze well at all. They sure don't communicate, and I seldom see students sitting around debating their classes. I'm not saying it doesn't happen at all, but it seems pretty rare. I find it baffling. I'm supposed to be surrounded with top students, but I mostly see students who lack the spark of curiosity and personal investment of even the most stoned Banana Slugs I knew back then.

What is up with these kids?
